subject: RE: [junit] Source of Junit
msgSnippet: No you don t need to understand the source to use it.  You only need to understand the examples given in the cook book. I ve written many tests without having
messageBody:
No you don't need to understand the source to use it. You only need to
understand the examples given in the cook book.

I've written many tests without having read the junit source code. I
have read the documentation and javadocs though.

-----Original Message-----
From: Alagusundaram Paulraj [mailto:apaulra@...]
Sent: 06 September 2001 20:10
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Source of Junit


To write Junit test case. should I understand all source programs.




Ramya TV wrote:

> You could also open the jar file with Winzip.
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Paul Michali [mailto:pcm@...]
> Sent: Thursday, September 06, 2001 4:27 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Source of Junit
> Guillaume Forget wrote:
> >
> > HI,
> >
> > I would like to get the source of JUnit 3.7
> > Is there any better way to get the java files than using the csv
system on
> > SourceForge
>
> Assuming you've installed JUnit on your system, in the JUnit3.7
> directory,
> there is a src.jar file (which is sorta like a TAR file, if you've
> worked
> with them). You can extract all the sources from that file using the
jar
> program from a command line:
>
> jar -xf src.jar
>
